citeinfo.origin: Katherine M. McClure, U.S. Geological Survey, Pacific Island Ecosystems Research Center
Rick J. Camp, U.S. Geological Survey, Pacific Island Ecosystems Research Center
Dennis A. LaPointe, U.S. Geological Survey, Pacific Island Ecosystems Research Center
Patrick Hart, University of Hawaii at Hilo
Bethany Woodworth, University of New England
Lucas Berio Fortini, U.S. Geological Survey, Pacific Island Ecosystems Research Center
citeinfo.title: Island of Hawaii bird, mosquito, and avian malaria infection data 2001-2004

descript.abstract: This data publication contains data files collected as part of a field, laboratory, and modeling effort aimed at uncovering ecological drivers of avian malaria transmission and impacts on Hawaiian honeycreepers across an elevational gradient on the eastern flank of Mauna Loa and Kilauea volcanoes on Hawaii Island. From 2001-2004, mosquito and bird data were collected at nine sites ranging 25 to 1,800 m above sea level. This data publication includes site and sampling coordinate data, mosquito capture data, mosquito avian malaria infection data, and point-transect distance sampling data. Site coordinate data consists of GPS spatial location data of sampling points where mosquitoes were captured and birds were surveyed to estimate abundance, comprising 45 points per site at 100 m intervals along five transects spaced 200 m apart. Mosquito capture data consists of counts of mosquitoes captured per trap night during 4-9 trapping nights per site per month over the study period. Mosquito infection data comprises avian malaria diagnostic data for a subset of captured mosquitoes that were dissected and malaria infection determined by microscopic examination of mosquito midguts and salivary glands. Point-transect distance sampling data consists of quarterly bird survey data in which observers recorded the horizontal distance of each sampling point to birds detected by sight and sound during 8-minute counts.
descript.purpose: These data were collected as part of a National Science Foundation Biocomplexity grant entitled the "Biocomplexity of Introduced Avian Diseases in Hawaii: Threats to Biodiversity of Native Forest Ecosystems". This work aimed to characterize mosquito-borne avian disease transmission and impacts on native Hawaiian birds using field-collected bird, mosquito, and mosquito-borne avian disease data.

place.placekey: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park Olaa Tract

citeinfo.title: Host population persistence in the face of introduced vector-borne diseases: Hawaii amakihi and avian malaria

serinfo.sername: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

pubinfo.publish: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

citeinfo.title: The dynamics, transmission, and population impacts of avian malaria in native Hawaiian birds: a modeling approach
Temporal Variation in Bird and Resource Abundance Across an Elevational Gradient in Hawaii

attracc.attraccr: Initial data entry and visual data checking of bird and mosquito data was conducted by field crews and supervised by field technicians and personnel. These data were then secondarily checked and cleaned using standard data science techniques by USGS-PIERC and Hawaii Cooperative Studies Unit personnel.

dataqual.logic: The data are logically consistent. The consistency was verified as part of the quality assurance that occurred during data analysis.
dataqual.complete: For the mosquito count data, we omitted data from gravid and CO2 traps that were either not functioning or were intentionally disabled or stolen. There are no missing data or omissions in the coordinate, count, or mosquito infection data.

horizpa.horizpar: Spatial coordinates of sampling points were obtained using a handheld Garmin GPS units, with a positional accuracy of approximately 30m.

vertacc.vertaccr: Spatial coordinates of sampling points were obtained using a handheld Garmin GPS unit, with a positional accuracy of approximately 30m.

procstep.procdesc:
We established nine 1km2 forested sites on the eastern flank of Mauna Loa and Kilauea volcanoes on the southeast corner of Hawaii Island (Woodworth et al. 2005, Samuel et al. 2011). Sites spanned a 1775 m elevational gradient, comprising three low elevation sites (<300 m), four mid-elevation sites (1,000-1,300 m), and two high-elevation sites (> 1,650 m). Each site contained five 1-km-long transects spaced 200m apart. On each transect, nine sampling points were established, each 100 m apart. All sites were located in secondary or primary forests dominated by native ohia trees (Meterosideros polymorpha) and a mix of native and introduced trees, shrubs, and ferns.
References: Samuel, M. D., P. H. F. Hobbelen, F. DeCastro, J. A. Ahumada, D. A. LaPointe, C. T. Atkinson, B. L. Woodworth, P. J. Hart, and D. C. Duffy. 2011. The dynamics, transmission, and population impacts of avian malaria in native Hawaiian birds: a modeling approach. Ecological Applications 21:2960–2973. Woodworth, B. L., C. T. Atkinson, D. A. Lapointe, P. J. Hart, C. S. Spiegel, E. J. Tweed, C. Henneman, J. Lebrun, T. Denette, R. Demots, K. L. Kozar, D. Triglia, D. Lease, A. Gregor, T. Smith, and D. Duffy. 2005. Host population persistence in the face of introduced vector-borne diseases: Hawaii amakihi and avian malaria. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA 102:1531–6.

We collected mosquitoes from February 2002 – December 2004 using Centers for Disease Control (CDC) light traps and oviposition (gravid) traps that target host-seeking and egg-laying females, respectively. Light traps were baited with approximately 300g of dry ice (CO2) and hung in trees at 4-12 m depending on forest canopy height (Sudia and Chamberlain 1967). Gravid traps were baited with alfalfa-infused water and traps placed on the forest floor (Reiter 1983, Bentley and Day 1989). We deployed a pair of light and gravid traps at 25 sampling locations per site at 4- to 6-week intervals. Sampling occurred for 4-9 nights of trapping per month, with traps set before sunset and mosquitoes collected the following morning. Captured Culex and Wyeomyia mosquitoes were identified to species and Aedes spp identified to genus by trained personnel in the field. Mosquitoes were counted and transported alive in holding cups to a laboratory, where Cx. quinquefasciatus mosquitoes were kept alive with a sucrose solution until dissection.
We conducted quarterly bird surveys at each site from March 2002 – December 2004 using point-transect distance sampling methods (Buckland et al. 2015, Hart et al. 2011). Counts were conducted at 25 stations located 200 m apart between 5:30 – 11am on a quarterly, or per season, basis. Observers estimated the horizontal distance from the sampling center point to individual birds that were detected visually or aurally. Observers also recorded the time of sampling, species, detection type (heard, seen, or both). Estimates for cloud cover, rain intensity, and wind and gust speed were also recorded, and surveys halted when sampling conditions exceeded light rain and/or wind and gust strength > 3 on the Beaufort scale. We categorized each species detected as one of three avian guilds—native, non-native, and gamebirds. Native birds included all Hawaiian endemic passerines and indigenous species. Gamebirds consisted of all Phasianidae (e.g. pheasants, grouse, etc.), and all other introduced bird species were categorized as non-natives.
References: Bentley, M. D., and J. F. Day. 1989. Chemical ecology and behavioral aspects of mosquito oviposition. Annual Review of Entomology 34:401–421. Buckland, S., E. Rexstad, T. Marques, and C. Oedekoven. 2015. Distance sampling: Methods and applications. Springer, London, UK. Hart, P. J., B. L. Woodworth, R. J. Camp, K. Turner, K. McClure, K. Goodall, C. Henneman, C. Spiegel, J. LeBrun, E. Tweed, and M. Samuel. 2011. Temporal variation in bird and resource abundance across an elevational gradient in Hawaii. Auk 128:113–126. Reiter, P. 1983. A portable, battery-operated trap for collecting gravid Culex mosquitoes. Mosquito News 43:496–498. Sudia, W. D., and R. W. Chamberlain. 1967. Collection and processing of medically important arthropods for arbovirus isolation. Page Center for Disease Control. Atlanta, GA.

Individual live-captured Culex quinquefasciatus were killed and dissected using standard techniques for identifying malaria infections in the midgut and salivary glands of mosquito vectors (Shute and Maryon 1960, World Health Organization 1975). Oocysts on the outer surface of the mosquito gut wall in infected mosquitoes were categorized by stage and counted as a measure of midgut infection intensity (small; medium; sporulated, i.e., containing differentiated sporozoites; ruptured; degenerating). We dissected the salivary glands and in infected mosquitoes ranked sporozoite intensity according to the number of sporozoites found within a 450x dissecting microscope field. Parity of the female mosquitoes was assessed and categorized as nulliparous (never laid eggs), parous (laid at least one egg raft), or gravid (with eggs) (Detinova et al. 1962). A wing was measured from each mosquito using a binocular microscope equipped with an ocular micrometer and was defined as the distance from the alular notch to the apical margin, excluding scale fringe.
References: Detinova, T. S., D. S. Bertram, and World Health Organization(WHO). 1962. Age-grouping methods in Diptera of medical importance, with special reference to some vectors of malaria. Page World Health Organization Monograph Series. Shute, P., and M. Maryon. 1960. Laboratory technique for the study of malaria. J&A Churchill Ltd., London. World Health Organization. 1975. Manual on practical entomology in malaria.

attr.attrdef: unique identifier of 1km2 study areas where data were collected.

CJ Ralph, Kamehameha Schools Bishop Estates, Keauhou
Crater Rim, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park
Pu'u Unit, Ola'a Tract of Hawaii Volcanoes National Park
Solomon’s Watering Hole, Kamehameha Schools Bishop Estates, Keauhou

attr.attrdef: One of nine points along each transect where mosquitoes were captured. Each station was spaced 100m apart along each transect. No stations occurred at the transect endpoints
One of five 1-km transects within each 1 km2 study grid, each spaced 200m apart

Unique alphanumeric identifier of site and number of capture periods that signified the number of monthly mosquito sampling bouts or periods at each site. Each sampling period consisted of multiple nights of mosquito sampling.

attrdomv.udom: alphanumeric value: site abbreviation + ordered number of mosquito sampling period

attr.attrdef: Date of mosquito capture. Trap operation started on the afternoon of the capture date and ended the following morning when mosquitoes were collected.
One of two adult-targeting baited mosquito traps (CO2 or gravid)

edom.edomvd: Centers for Disease Control (CDC) light trap, baited with approximately 300g of dry ice (CO2) and hung in trees at 4-12 m depending on forest canopy height.
CDC gravid trap (JW Hock Company) baited with alfalfa-infused water.

attr.attrdef: Total number of adult female Culex quinquefasciatus in trap
Total number of adult female Aedes spp. in trap
Total number of adult female Wyeomyia mitchelli in trap

enttyp.enttypl: Biocomplexity_mosquito avian malaria infection and parity data.csv

attr.attrdef: unique identifier of 1km2 study areas where data were collected.

Puu Unit, Ola'a Tract of Hawaii Volcanoes National Park
Crater Rim, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park
CJ Ralph, Kamehameha Schools Bishop Estates, Keauhou

attr.attrdef: One of nine points along each transect where sampling occurred. Each station was spaced 100m apart along each transect. No stations occurred at the transect endpoints.
One of five 1-km transects within each 1 km2 study grid. Each transect was spaced 200m apart.
One of two adult-targeting baited mosquito traps (CO2 or gravid)

edom.edomvd: Centers for Disease Control (CDC) light trap, baited with approximately 300g of dry ice (CO2) and hung in trees at 4-12 m depending on forest canopy height.
CDC gravid trap (JW Hock Company) baited with alfalfa-infused water.

attr.attrdef: The date of mosquito capture. Represents the hours of trap operation starting on the afternoon of the capture date and ending on the morning of the following day when mosquitoes were collected.
The date when mosquitoes were dissected.
Mosquito species dissected
Wing length converted from MU to millimeters with the aid of a stage micrometer.

edom.edomvd: No data because measurement was not taken.

attr.attrdef: Parity (i.e. whether or not a mosquito has produced a mature batch of eggs) as determined by ovarial tracheolation. Provides information on physiological age of the mosquito and gives an indication if the mosquito has had a blood meal (host contact).

edom.edomvd: No data because the ovary was not successfully removed or prepared.
Never having produced mature eggs. Ovarial tracheoles appear as tight bundles or skeins on the surface of ovary under 450X.
Mosquito has produced at least one raft of matured eggs. Ovarial tracheoles are unwound and loose on the ovary as observed at 450X.

attr.attrdef: Whether or not early stage parasites (oocysts) are present on the mosquito midgut as determined by Nomarski microscopy at 450 x.

edom.edomvd: No data available. Midgut not dissected or slide preparation unreadable.
No oocysts present in the midgut

attr.attrdef: The number of small oocysts with a diameter in the range of the 10-20 microns. Size was determined subjectively.
The number of medium oocysts with a diameter in the range of the 21-49 microns. Size was determined subjectively.
The number of large, sporulated oocysts with a diameter in the range of the 50-60 microns. Size was determined subjectively.
The number of ruptured oocysts (shells) present on the midgut.
The number of degenerated oocysts present on the midgut. Degenerated oocysts are shrunken and melanized.
salivary gland infection = whether or not infective stage parasites (sporozoites) are present in the mosquito salivary gland as determined by Nomarski microscopy at 450x.

edom.edomvd: No Data available. Salivary gland not dissected or slide preparation unreadable.
No sporozoites observed in the slaivary glands. Not infective.
Sporozoites observed in the salivary glands of the mosquito. Individual is infective.

attr.attrdef: Sporozoite intensity = subjective scale based on the number of sporozoites observed in a single microscopic field with the most sporozoites.

edom.edomvd: No data available. Salivary gland not dissected or slide preparation unreadable.

edom.edomvd: Warbling White-eye (formerly Japanese White-eye), Zosterops japonicus

attr.attrdef: Distance, measured to the nearest meter, at which a bird was detected
Category of detection type
Number of surveys conducted at the sampling point on a given survey date (1 or 2).
One of three avian guilds that characterized the detected bird: native, non-native, and gamebirds.

edom.edomvd: Native birds – Native bird species, i.e. Hawaiian endemic passerines and indigenous species
Non-native birds - Non-Phasianidae introduced bird species
Gamebirds – Game birds, i.e. bird species within the Phasianidae family, all introduced

attr.attrdef: Three-character code representing bird counters. Complete names have been withheld to maintain counter anonymity.
Date when survey was conducted.
Time when the survey began.
Percent of cloud cover (scaled linearly from 0-100 by tens)
Intensity of rain.
Wind strength according to the Beaufort scale
Gust strength according to the Beaufort scale.

overview.eaover: This section of the XML includes one ‘Detailed’ tab for each of the four CSV files included in this data release: (1) site and sampling coordinate data, (2) mosquito capture data, (3) mosquito avian malaria infection data, and (4) point-transect distance sampling data.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
